sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: With dignity .Cover your own heart , Padahoon , lest I ask what mischief breeds in it to bid you observe me so much . I have not forgot that you would have paid me a blanket to be made war leader in the room of Simwa .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: With ugly insinuation .Ugh ! huh ! Perhaps I had been as fortunate as the Arrow-Maker , if , instead of giving it , I had offered to share it with you .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Kima ! Padahoon , you do tempt me to try if I can curse .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Conciliatory .I have no wish to anger the friend of the gods , but I am a plain man wishing good to my campody , and it seems not good to me that Simwa has grown suddenly so great .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Recovering herself .What has that to do with the Chisera ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: I have known this Simwa since he was first tied in a basket , and , though he has grown to be war leader , I think he is most like a pod of rattleweed that is swollen to twice its size at the end of the season , yet has no more in it than at the beginning . And I do not know how , without the help of magic medicine , he has come to be what he is with so little in him .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: The Chief 's daughter has trusted him .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: She loves him .During this scene bursts of Indian music and singing have been heard at intervals . It grows louder . PADAHOON and CHISERA look off .They come this way , Chisera . You are right . When a man has married so fair a wife , there is not much left to be done for him .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: With bitter irony , as she moves over against SIMWA 'S hut and puts up her blanket .I am not so sure .

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: It is Chisera .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: With alarm .Where is my daughter ?

div.stage: BRIGHT WATER enters with the young girls , laughing and talking . Her hair is braided with golden poppies and falls over her shoulders . She sees the CHISERA standing , tall and still , by SIMWA 'S hut , her whole figure shrouded in a blanket , which is drawn up to cover all of her face but the eyes .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Who is it comes to my wedding uninvited ? How her eyes burn upon me !

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Hush ! She will hear you . It is the Chisera .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: The Chisera ? Never have I seen her like this . But she has come to bring me a blessing .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Do not speak to her , my daughter ; she is not in the humor for it .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Shall I not be courteous to the first guest who has come to my husband 's house ? Chisera , I am pleased that you have come to bless my marriage .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Out of her blanket .Where is Simwa ?

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: He comes soon .Going to her .Last night I thought of you , and how you alone , of all Sagharawite , had kept away from my happiness —

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Let be , daughter .Pulling her sleeve .It is ill stirring a coiled snake .To the CHISERA , with intent to draw her off .Come this way , Chisera , and I will show you the wedding presents .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Lowering her blanket a little .Show me the Arrow-Maker .

div.stage: The elder men have entered , among them RAIN WIND .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: What is this ?

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: It is the Chisera asking for Simwa .

sp.speaker: MEN
sp.p: Ah ! ah ! ah — ah !

div.stage: Exchanging glances of inquiry and amazement .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Who is that behind her ?

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Padahoon !

sp.speaker: MEN
sp.p: Ugh ! huh !

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: So ? Why does she cover her face ?

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: She makes medicine in her blanket .

div.stage: The Indians draw close in two groups , the women together and the men on the other side . They watch the CHISERA uneasily . BRIGHT WATER stands a little apart , the bridesmaids moving timidly toward the elder women .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Putting down her blanket .The Arrow-Maker of Sagharawite is slow to the bridal .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: He comes . He comes .

div.stage: The young men enter , with SIMWA in their midst , painted and befeathered as befits a handsome man on his wedding day . Observing the CHISERA , he checks and falters in his walk .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Chisera !

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Is it you , Simwa , who wed with the Chief 's daughter ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: You are come , Chisera —Wholly at a loss .You are come —

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: I am come to your marriage , Simwa , though I am not invited .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: But now that she is here , Simwa , you will ask her to bless us ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Recovering himself with an effort .Surely , surely . But the married women have not blessed us yet .Taking the bride 's hand and leading her to the blanket . They seat themselves .Come , Tiawa , have you no pine nuts in your basket ?With an effort to carry it off jovially .What ! will you have my wife dig roots before her wedding year is out ?

div.stage: The married women take up their baskets and begin the ceremony of sprinkling the bride with nuts and seeds in token of fruitfulness .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Warningly .Simwa ! Simwa !

div.stage: The women leave off , huddling together , looking fearfully at the CHISERA .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Getting between her and BRIGHT WATER .What harm to you , Chisera , if the Arrow-Maker weds where he loves ?

lg.l: Aye — where he loves —
Simwa ! Simwa !

div.stage: She drops her blanket and turns away .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Lifting her basket to her shoulder again .Let us go on with the marriage .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: To the company .If the Chisera knows any reason why this marriage should not go on , should she not say it openly ? A word half spoken breeds suspicion faster than flies at killing time .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: What talk is this of reasons ? Have I not the disposing of my daughter in marriage ? Reason enough , if I wish it so .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: That which is most reasonable to men , the gods see otherwise .

div.stage: A murmur begins in the camp , but SIMWA takes it up instantly .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: He is thinking of the war with Castac . Truly , you were not eye to eye with the gods on that occasion , Padahoon .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Were I so sure it was of the gods , I had not stood out so against it .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Was not Simwa approved of the gods through the mouth of the Chisera ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: So you think .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Is there another Arrow-Maker so skilled between Tehachappi and Tecuya ? Are any shafts better fashioned to fly straight to the mark ? Is there any hunter knows more surely where the herds feed , or strikes quicker the slot of a deer ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: As you think .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Let be this talk of reasons . This is mere woman 's mischief , to nod and wink and to make signs with the eyebrows . A woman would have you think reason enough for marrying if she liked or misliked it . Chisera , this is no matter for the gods , but a plain mating of man and maid .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Flashing .Since when have you talked with the gods , that you think to lesson me in their business ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Since you have been a father , to know reasons for the bestowal of daughters .

div.stage: Grunts of appreciation .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Letting her blanket slip to her breast .Know , then , that if these are your reasons , Rain Wind , there is no more meat in them than in the husk of acorns . If good fortune hangs on all Simwa 's movements , it is by reason of the medicine I make that binds him in the favor of the Friend .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Leaning on his elbows , with the manner of being quite at ease .You are very free with your blessing , Chisera , if it is so ; for it is well known in the camp that Simwa , the Arrow-Maker , does not believe in charms , nor seek them .

sp.speaker: INDIANS
sp.p: Grunting in assent .Ugh ! huh !

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Letting fall her blanket in a burst of indignation .“ Nor seek them !”— Ah ! Simwa ! Simwa !

div.stage: A short pause of embarrassment and consternation ensues . Then PADAHOON , in a manner meant to seem impartial —

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: The medicine of the Chisera is very powerful , but one must allow a little credit to the gods . Simwa was chosen war leader by the trial of the seven sticks . As the gods willed , they made the sticks to fall . Is it not so , Chisera ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Sullenly , from her blanket .I do not know . I did not look .Letting fall her blanket and speaking proudly .I had persuaded the Friend to give victory to the war leader . What should I care for the sticks ? A day and a night I made medicine , and the sign was sure . I said “ Simwa ” and the gods confirmed it .

div.stage: The Indians remain silent , but draw a little away from SIMWA .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Rising and turning toward her .Chisera , why should you make medicine for Simwa ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Chief 's daughter , do not ask .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Chief 's daughter I am , and wife of the war leader . Why should you concern yourself with his affairs ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: After a pause , with great dignity .Because he loved me .

sp.speaker: INDIANS
sp.p: Ah ! Ah — ah ! Ah !

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Laughing .The Friend of the gods has eaten rattleweed . Does a man love a wild woman who goes muttering and waving her arms , when she should be weaving and grinding meal ? Would he take a wander-thought to his bed , and have witless children ? Sooner I had a snake in my hut to run and tattle to the gods of me .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: To PADAHOON .Now , if it is true that he owes his fortune to the gods , they have deserted him , else he would not speak so to a jealous woman .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Looking long at the CHISERA , haggard and unpainted , her blanket trailing , and then to the Chief 's daughter , and back again , all the eyes of the campody following .Is there any comeliness in a witch , that a man should desire her ?

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Alarmed .Simwa , Simwa ! If you have no care for yourself , at least remember my daughter !

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Rising .Have no care , mother . If I do not believe she can bless , neither do you believe that she can curse .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Mother , let be . If this be true that she speaks , I am already cursed .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Going to his wife .What have we to do with blessings or cursings ? The Chisera is unsound in her mind . I have seen her dancing in the hills sometimes where I went to gather eagle 's feathers for my arrows , and her madness has made a curious tale of it .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: I would I might believe it .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: With returning complacency .Do you find it so hard to have a husband whom other women admire ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Chief and tribesmen , if it be true that Simwa values charms so little , let him declare what it is he keeps sewed in his quiver so precious that he must hide it even on his wedding day .

div.stage: Murmurs . The CHISERA , in alarm , endeavors to check PADAHOON . SIMWA turns upon him with a snarl .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Kima !Wildly .You cannot prove that I had it of the Chisera !

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Suddenly darting out two fingers from his mouth , moving them rapidly in the manner of a snake 's tongue , with a hissing sound .Snake of two tongues ! Now I know you for the man you are , braggart and liar !

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Coyote whelp !

div.stage: SIMWA grasps a war weapon , a stone tied in a crotched stick , from the heap of wedding gifts , and smites PADAHOON to the earth , standing threateningly over him . The others stiffen into tense attitudes , drawing their blankets tighter , their eyes burning bright . PADAHOON draws the knife that hangs in a sheath at his neck .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Putting SIMWA back with a hand at his breast .Peace ! Though you are made my son by this day 's work , you shall not usurp judgment .To PADAHOON , as SIMWA moves slowly back , his weapon lowered .What charge do you make ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Rising on his elbow to spit blood .Thou art a liar , if ever there was one in Sagharawite , and have nothing which is not owed to the Chisera .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Speak straight , Padahoon , or , by the Bear , I shall let him kill you where you lie .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Three nights after the return from Tecuya , I saw you at the Chisera 's house — and again in the rains — and at the time of Taboose .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Is it so , Chisera ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: It is so .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Did you go there for love or profit ?

div.stage: SIMWA lets slip his weapon from his hand to the ground .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Simwa , if you were the son of my body , I should not know which to believe .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Believe him if you like .Sullenly .If a skunk walk in my trail and leave a stink there , shall I go out of my way to deny that it is mine ? No doubt the woman is both mad and shameless .

div.stage: Murmurs of indignation .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Afraid , but furious .Then if you are shameless , begone ! Stay not to vex the marriage of a maiden . Go ! Have to do with your gods , and leave my daughter .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Mother ! Mother !

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Shameless , am I , Seegooche ? Then there is one of your blood shall know a greater shame . Great hunter does she think her man ? Aye , but she shall come to dig roots for him when he fails of the hunt and be glad of the offal the other women give her for pity . For this I say to you , tribesmen of Sagharawite , that , though I cannot curse , yet I can take back my blessing .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: All this is of no account , Chisera . No doubt you can contrive against the fame of Simwa and bespeak the gods to neglect him ; I wait to hear what proof you have that he loved you .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Do not vex her , daughter , lest she turn the gods against you also .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: No matter , mother . What Simwa bears , I can bear . What proof , Chisera ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: What proof ?

div.stage: She turns toward SIMWA , faltering . He smiles contemptuously .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: That Simwa loved you .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Slowly , her eyes on SIMWA .He came to my hut — in the night — Chief 's daughterboldly, even as he comes this night to yours .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Impatiently .But did he love you ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: He made me so believe .Looking about and noting the lack of conviction .How else had he held me , since last the poppies bloomed , a lure to snare the favor of the gods ? Does he say he was not blessed ? Aye , twice blessed .She takes from her bosom the amulet .Was it not this you gave me to make medicine upon , to keep your lover safe in war ? Twice blessed he was ; but , as I made my blessing , so do I break it .

div.stage: Drops the amulet and grinds it underfoot .

sp.speaker: INDIANS
sp.p: Moving uneasily .Ah ! Ah !

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: And this is the proof that I speak truly . From this day , whoever brings me arrows shall have medicine upon them without price , and who would have news of the passing of the deer shall have it for the asking . Only Simwa shall have nothing but his own wit and the work of his hands , and by what befalls , you shall know the truth .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: By this I know the truth ! You never loved him , or you would not now betray him .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Moving toward the trail .And you , Bright Water , that think to lie in your husband 's arms this night , know that I have lain there before you . And you shall not dare to laugh as a bride laughs , lest it be to him my voice in the dusk ; and if he turns and sighs in his sleep , you shall wonder if he dreams of the Chisera . Long and anxiously you shall look in the trail when he is late from the hunt , and the men shall mock him that he could not keep the blessing he had got .BRIGHT WATER turns despairingly and sinks on the ground , holding her mother by the knees and sobbing bitterly . All the Indians draw away from SIMWA , leaving him standing , discomfited , in the middle of the camp . All look with awe and dread at the CHISERA . She produces a small medicine stick from under her blanket and twirls it with menace . Going .As for you , Arrow-Maker of Sagharawite , though I cannot curse , yet am I the friend of the gods , and they have regard to me . Look well to yourself , Simwa . Look well .

div.stage: CURTAIN

div.head: ACT THIRD

sp.speaker: ACT THIRD
sp.p: TIME .— One year later .

sp.speaker: SCENE .— The top of Toorape , where the tribe has been driven by their
sp.p: enemies of Tecuya . The women and children hide in holes in the rocks . Off to the right on a jutting boulder , against the sky , stands YAVI , as sentinel ; two or three wounded lie about . Crouching over the fire are SEEGOOCHE , WACOBA , and TIAWA , showing in their dress and appearance the marks of a year of distress , as do all the others as they appear upon the scene .

sp.speaker: YAVI
sp.p: To them .St — st !

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Rising .Some one on the trail !

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: To her .Hush !

sp.speaker: YAVI
sp.p: The Sparrow Hawk !

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: News from the Fighting Men !

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: The gods grant it be good news !

div.stage: PADAHOON , weary and with disordered dress , comes clambering up the face of the cliff .

sp.speaker: YAVI
sp.p: Calling down in a whisper .What news ?

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: Are the gods still against us ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: As they have been since the day the Chisera took away her blessing from the war leader .

sp.speaker: WOMEN
sp.p: Wailing .Ai ! Ai !

div.stage: Others come out of the rocks to join in the general grief .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Could you but persuade her to give it back again .Hopefully .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: If I cannot , then this is like to be the last fight of Sagharawite !

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: If you cannot , then must the chief enforce her , for since we were driven from our homes , neither the anguish of the women nor the hunger of the children has moved her .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: I will speak with her at once .

div.stage: He goes up among the rocks , and the women huddle wretchedly together watching .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Do you think she will consent ?

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: She cannot choose but do it . The men have kept her supplied with venison , but she must know that there is hunger in the camp of the women and children .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: And that the Tecuyas have taken the best of our fighting men .

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: But no man of hers . I have always said — but because I am old nobody minds me — that if there was one of her household to go to battle , she would need no persuasion to go before the gods . I would Simwa had given her a child .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Aside from SEEGOOCHE .Then you believe that he was her lover ?

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: What else ? Would any but a jilted woman sit and mope while our wickiups go up in smoke ?

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: I would she had a child , but not Simwa 's . One of that breed is enough .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Who has moved nearer the hut .Hush , see the curtain !They start .

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: It was the wind .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: They say she has not made medicine since my daughter 's marriage .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Looking off to the right where the mountains dip abruptly valleyward .And to think that even now they must be fighting under Toorape .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Hush ! Hush !

div.stage: PADAHOON and the CHISERA come out of the hut . The CHISERA 'S whole appearance is of heartbreak and neglect . She leans against the boulders at the left , holding her blanket close , and answers PADAHOON sullenly .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: And is this all your answer ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: The trail is cold between the gods and me .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Then you will not make medicine ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: And would not if I could .

lg.l: Have you turned renegade , Chisera , and side with our enemies of
Tecuya ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: No , Padahoon , but I see that no good comes of persuading the gods to do more for man than his natural destiny .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: You have always persuaded them to our advantage .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: What good came of having Simwa made war leader ? Had I not persuaded them to meddle with that business , the leadership would have fallen to you as the elder , and we should not now be without allies in our need .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: I am not sure the gods had so much to do with that : but if the mischief came through them , the gods must repair it .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: I will not make medicine . Send the women away .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: What shall I say to them ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: To count themselves already blessed in having those for whom they desire blessing . Tell them that to have loved and given the breast is enough to salve the wounds of loss .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: You are hard , Chisera .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: I am jealous of their griefs . Their very pangs I envy them . Who is there of mine goes to this war that I should grieve for his wounding or look for his return ?She looks bitterly toward the women who have crept from the caves to peer from the rocks in the direction of the fighting .Persuade me no more , Padahoon . I will not do it .

div.stage: She disappears among the rocks to the left , and PADAHOON turns to the women who crowd around him anxiously .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Has she promised ?

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: Will she help us ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: The Chisera will not make medicine .

sp.speaker: WOMEN
sp.p: Rocking themselves to and fro .Ai ! Ai !

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Is it because our gifts are so small ? She should consider how hard it is to get venison in war-time .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Her heart is so full of bitterness that there is no room in it for the gods .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: That is Simwa 's doing — though he is your son , Seegooche , I must say it — there was no better Chisera between here and Tehachappi until he curdled her wisdom with his lies .

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: Ah , Simwa ! I spit upon his name .

div.stage: The women spit between their teeth with sharp hisses .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: How the Chisera hates him !

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: How she loves him !

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: Struck with this .You think so ? Yet there is not one word of the evil she said of him a year ago that has not come to pass .

sp.speaker: WOMEN
sp.p: Ai ! Ai ! On him and us .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: And hate would have been satisfied to strip him of his honors , but now she lets the whole tribe go down in the ruin of her love .

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Hopefully .Then if she loves him , perhaps he can persuade her .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: As well persuade the rattlesnake not to strike him .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: If the Chief should insist , she would not dare refuse .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: There is little she would not dare . But you can try .

sp.speaker: WOMEN
sp.p: Let us bring the Chief .They go out .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Reappearing cautiously .Have they gone ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: To bring Rain Wind to command you .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Can he command the sap to rise or bid the deer-weed spring when there is no rain ? My power is gone from me .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Chisera , it is a grave matter to refuse service in time of war — be advised by the word of a friend —

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Has the Chisera indeed a friend ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Have I not proved —

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Padahoon , when did you ever visit me for any but your own advantage ? For what else did you stir me against Simwa , and why now do you seek my blessing but to make good against him the honor of which he has robbed you ? Does any one of you bring me venison except for profit or grind my meal for love ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Seeing how little good you had of the love of the Arrow-Maker , why should you desire it ?

lg.l: You spit poison like a toad , Padahoon , but your fangs are drawn . The
Arrow-Maker never loved me .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Approaching her with the manner of having gained a point .If you have the wit to know so much —

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Commanding him from her with a gesture as she seats herself .Padahoon , there is no more power in me than there is tang in a wet bowstring .She rocks her head between her hands .It is gone from me as the shadow goes up the mountain . As the wild geese go northward at the end of the rains , so is my power — How shall I win it again who cannot win the love of man ?... Ah , leave me , Padahoon , leave me !

div.stage: She covers her head with her blanket .

Enter CHIEF RAIN WIND , stumbling blindly , led by his wife and followed at a respectful distance by the other women . He walks with dignity , in spite of his blindness , and has on all the insignia of rank except the war-bonnet . SEEGOOCHE has a hasty , eager manner , ingratiating but timid .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: To them .You will get nothing .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: I do not come asking : I command .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: No , no , do not be harsh with her ! Let me speak , we women will understand one another .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Putting his wife aside .Chisera .The CHISERA starts at the tone of authority , but controls herself .Friend of the gods .She makes a movement of protest .I have that to say to you which should be said but once , which to say at all is shame to you . Great powers have been given you to turn the favor of the gods as a willow is turned in the wind . How is it you have not turned them when your people are in war and bad fortune ? We are driven as hunted rabbits to hide in holes in the rocks , and our fighting men are outnumbered ; even now we do not know if there be one left alive of them — Our tribe shall be as a forgotten tale unless you intercede for us .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Over her shoulder .What ? Is it possible Simwa cannot bring this affair to pass without the gods ?

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Breaking in eagerly .Yes , yes ; the gods are very great , there is nothing without them .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Still to the CHIEF .Does Simwa ask it ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: The chief commands it .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Cringingly .No . No . Chisera , mind him not ! He is not himself , the hunger and the loss of battle do distress him . We beg of you , we implore you , Chisera — we will bring gifts to you — gifts , Chisera .She looks about despairingly for a suitable gift , snatches a great rope of beads from the Chief 's neck and drops it in the CHISERA 'S lap .Spoil of our enemies when the war is over , and this to keep as a reminder — So — if only you will persuade the gods to friend us .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Lifting the collar and letting it fall .And if I will not ?

div.stage: Still with her eyes on the CHIEF , ignoring Seegooche .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Chisera , I am an old man , and I knew your father . We had much good talk together — I am very old — but I am not blind in my judgment as I am in my eyes . In war-time there is but one law for those faithless to the tribal obligation . You know it .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Drawing her blanket .I know it .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Dropping to the ground and beating the earth with her palms .Do not , do not refuse it , wise one , friend of the Friend ! What has Simwa done that you should destroy us ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: You ask me that , Seegooche ?

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: I know — you said — Such a small thing , Chisera . To love you a little before he loved my daughter . Young men do often so — and you were very fair and no doubt beguiled him — Ah , who could withstand you , daughter of the gods ?Wheedling .But your punishment is heavy upon him .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Is it so ?

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Thinking she has gained a point .It is indeed as you said ; he makes no more arrows , and his luck in the hunt is gone from him . And the men mock him . A war leader should not be mocked , Chisera .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: No more should a friend of the gods , but Simwa mocked me .

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Loosing hope .He was mad , Chisera , he had eaten rattle-weed . But my daughter did not mock you . Think of my daughter !

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: When does your daughter ever think of me ?

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: Broken and drooping .Every day she thinks of you . When she is a-hungered , when her man brings her nothing from the hunt — as — you have said , Chisera . When she digs roots with the old women and no one prevents her for the sake of a child to be born .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: With relish .Does she dig roots ?

sp.speaker: SEEGOOCHE
sp.p: With the barren women . Also her beauty goes , she is so thin with the famine .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Baring her arm .I also am thin .

div.stage: From this moment some perception of the pervasive misery of the situation enters her mind and begins to color her speech .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Hunger and sickness and war have come into the camp because you kept not your heart , Chisera . Yet a greater than all these shall come upon you if you forget your tribal obligation .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Rising on one knee .What obligation have I owed , Chief Rain Wind , and not remembered it ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: That which lies upon all that have power with the Friend of the Soul of Man . Only the gods can save us , and only you know the true and acceptable road to them .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Rising and moving toward her hut .I am overweary for the road ; let Simwa find it .

div.stage: An arrow , with a feather and a fragment of bark attached to it , is shot into the camp from the direction of the fighting . PADAHOON takes it up and carries it to the CHIEF , the others crowding about .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: What was that ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: A message from the Fighting Men .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Read me the token .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: A vulture 's feather and a bark of whenonabe . Defeat and flight .

sp.speaker: WOMEN
sp.p: Ai ! Ai !

div.stage: They throw up their arms in despair .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: They will not be far behind their arrows .

div.stage: All listen . A faint whoop is heard . PADAHOON answers with his mouth covered with his hands . The rest of the women and children come out of the rocks . Fighting Men come clambering up the steep . They show torn clothing and streaks of blood . The women bring them the water-bottles as they drop upon the ground . WACOBA 'S husband , PAMAQUASH , with an arrow in his side , leaps once in air and drops dead . His wife sinks on the ground beside him , rocking and moaning . One breaks his unstrung bow across his knees and stamps the pieces in the earth . Finally comes SIMWA , his war-bonnet bedraggled .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Ugh ! Is it so I find the fighting men of Sagharawite — huddled together like rabbits when the coyotes are after them ?

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Scattering dust on her head .Ai ! Ai ! My man , my man !

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Be still , you fool ! Would you call up our enemies with your noise ?The wailing drops to a moan .Put out that fire — they can sniff smoke as far as a vulture smells carrion .CHOCO stamps out the fire .You , Choco , do you show your face to me , misgotten whelp of a coyote ! It was you who led the fleeing .

sp.speaker: CHOCO
sp.p: Sullenly .It was Tavwots .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: By the Bear , you shall have a wound for that , though you ran too fast to have one in battle .

div.stage: He draws the obsidian knife at his belt .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Fools !He strikes up TAVWOTS ’ arm ; another Indian jerks CHOCO by the ankles causing him to sit down .Have you killed so many in battle , Tavwots , that you can afford to lose us a fighting man ?

div.stage: The men subside , exhausted .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Peace ! Though I am too old for battle , yet am I master in the camp . What has happened ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: We have shown the Tecuyas what running is like .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: The gods send we have run fast enough to throw them off the trail , else they will attack before morning .

div.stage: Consternation among the women .

lg.l: Kima !
lg.stage: Their grief falls off to a whimper . To SIMWA .
lg.l: Where met you ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Under Waban where they stayed to cook venison they had killed . We had every way the advantage —

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: As much as rabbits when they have met with coyotes . They were three to one of us .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Ignoring him with an effort .We were between them and cover — we were driving them toward Waban — but they sent one out against us armed — Chief and father , how do you think he was armed who put the sons of the Bear to flight ? With a stick — a painted stick with feathers on it .Angry and protesting murmurs .An old man with a stick , Rain Wind , and they ran before him like squaws who deserve a beating ! Faugh !Native movement of disgust .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: Rising on his elbow .You shall be sicker , Simwa , when you have eaten your words . That old man was Tibu , the medicine man of the Tecuyas . I knew him .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Then it was you , Tavwots , who broke and ran ?

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: He came upon us with charms and spells . He had the gods on his side .

sp.speaker: CHOCO
sp.p: Our hearts were turned to water because of his evil medicine .

lg.l: Are not the gods of Sagharawite stronger than the gods of the
Tecuyas ?

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: Not when we have one to lead us who despises their blessings .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Well , I believe in the medicine of Tibu . He has made old women of you .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Think no more of that . Let us consider what is to be done .

div.stage: Shadows of vultures appear on the rocks , attracted by the dead . WACOBA springs up from casting dust upon her head to flap them away with her blanket , which she spreads over the body of her husband .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: As he motions to the men to move the body near the shelter .Yes , it is time to take counsel when the birds of the air betray us to our enemies .

div.stage: The women gather together about the dead . One of them takes the place of the sentry who comes to Council . The men collect near the CHISERA 'S hut with the exception of SIMWA , who remains seated , re-stringing his bow . BRIGHT WATER goes to him .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Simwa , how long will you let your pride destroy us ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Is that a word for a man 's wife ?

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: It is a true one . Do we not know , you and I , that it is but pride that makes you stand out against the friend of the gods ? Look at me , Simwa , is it not proved on my body that she spoke truly when she said that you throve only by her blessing ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Can you bear to admit so much ?

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Bear ? What have I not borne ? Have I complained when I dig roots ? Have I quivered when I was mocked ? Has there been any sign of shame on my face for all the scorne on theirs ? Have I said , “ Give me children ,” when the nursing mothers pitied me ? Oh , I have borne , I have borne ; but this I cannot bear .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: What is now so hard ?

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: To know that you and I know the truth and that you will see the tribe wiped out before you will admit it .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: The truth ?

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: That you were the Chisera 's lover for the sake of what she could do for you , and your denial left her no way to prove it except by taking away the help of the gods from us all . Is not that the truth ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Would you have me ashamed before all men ?

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: When have I not been ashamed since I married you ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Let her alone ! They will kill her if she refuses to make medicine and then we shall be rid of her .

lg.l: And you would permit that ?
lg.stage: He shifts uneasily under her gaze .
lg.l: Simwa —
Simwa !

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: What is the witch to me ?

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: My sister , I think , for she has loved you even as I have , to my sorrow .

div.stage: She turns away from him meditating some deep purpose , and from this time on the progress of that purpose in her mind is evident in her bearing toward her husband .

lg.l: Let the Council sit .
lg.stage: They sit as in ACT I .
lg.l: Simwa , as war leader , what plan have you ?

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: It wants not plans so much as men to do them .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Whatever is in any man 's mind for the good of the tribe , let it be delivered . Observe not the rule of the elders , but speak at once .A moment , during which black looks are cast at SIMWA .Will no one speak ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Chief and tribesmen , once I gave counsel and you despised it —

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: No more of that . Give counsel now .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: It is the same counsel , but time has not mended the occasion . Penned here on the edge of the precipice we can but starve . We must break through our enemies and strike at their women and their stores .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: Every trail is watched . Not so much as a weasel can go in and out from Toorape and they not know it .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: With so many watchers , then , they cannot have much of a fighting force at any point . In an hour it will be dark ; we shall go down by Deer Leap with the women and children , and stay not for fighting , but , fleeing for our lives , break through to their villages —

sp.speaker: CHOCO
sp.p: But if they move on us to-night ? If the vultures have already betrayed us — even now they may be within earshot ?

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: If they come up with us before we reach Deer Leap it is to run into the wolf 's mouth .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: I have thought of that . To-night they expect us to mourn our dead and go before our gods —

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: So should we .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: That they may think so , leave one behind to sound the medicine drum throughout the night . So they shall fear to attack and expect an easier victory in the morning when we are exhausted with dancing to the gods .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: But he that stays , what shall become of him —

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: He shall die as becomes himrising— as becomes a chief of his people .

div.stage: Murmurs of consternation and then silence .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: But another — whose counsels we prize less —

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: It is the tribal use . None else too blind for the trail and too feeble for the sortiewith grim humor— but I can drum .Solemn grunts of approval .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: If we win through Deer Leap , we can make terms for you . Tribesmen , what say you ?A pause .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: What I say is for myself only ; but I go not out against the Tecuyas again unless the Chisera has blessed the going .

sp.speaker: THE COUNCIL
sp.p: Good counsel ; good counsel ! He has it !

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: There are two or three things to the making of fighting men , Tavwots , beside the blessing of women .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: Two or three things , Simwa , that I think you have not : honor to win advantage and wit to keep what you have got .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: As for me , I am with Tavwots ; buthe looks at SIMWA— the gods have no favors for unbelievers .

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: Nor have we , by the Bear !

sp.speaker: INDIANS
sp.p: Springing up .Nor have we ! No ; by the Bear ! Out with him !They hustle SIMWA . One snatches off the war-bonnet , another the collar of bears ’ claws . Even the women strike dust upon him with their feet in an excess of contempt .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Peace , tribesmen !

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: Perhaps we shall have peace when we have a leader against whom neither the gods nor women have a spite . Tribesmen , who shall lead the going out but he who planned it ?

lg.l: Hi ! Hi ! Padahoon ! Padahoon !
lg.stage: They fling the collar about his neck . TAVWOTS hands him the bonnet .
lg.l: Hi ! Hi ! The Sparrow Hawk .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Do not count on me too much with the Chisera ; all this time I have kept in camp with my wound I have reasoned with her , but still she refuses me .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: There shall be an end to that —

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: How then —?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Who denies service to the tribe in extremity must be dealt with as an enemy .Consternation .

sp.speaker: CHOCO
sp.p: But a friend of the gods —

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: Let the gods save her —

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: There are times when the gods must be content to stand still and see what men will do . Who serves not us , serves our enemies . It is the law .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Reluctantly .It is the law —

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Death or good medicine — Speak , tribesmen !

div.stage: Above the silence of the Council is heard the deep , excited breathing of the women .

sp.speaker: THE COUNCIL
sp.p: One after another .Death . Death . Death or good medicine . It is the law .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: To PADAHOON .Bid her come .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: At the hut .Chisera , come to Council !

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Issuing , wrapped in her blanket .Who sends for me ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Death is hot upon our trail . Stay him with your spells .

sp.speaker: MEN AND WOMEN
sp.p: Good medicine , Chisera , good medicine !

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Have you not a war leader —

div.stage: She stops , noticing the bonnet on PADAHOON — looks from him to SIMWA .

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Who invites your blessing , Chisera !

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Make spells for thy people !

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: What have my people done for me that I should weary myself to make medicine for them ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Are you not respected above all women of the campody ? Even in war-time —

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Ah — respect ! What have I to do with respect ? Am I not as other women that men should desire me ? Are my breasts less fair that there should never be milk in them ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: We honor you after the use of medicine men . What more would you have ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: The dole of women . Love and sorrow and housekeeping ; a husband to give me children , even though he beat me .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Love you have given , and sorrow you have got . Shame and defeat are your children . So it is always when power falls upon women . The word has passed in Council , Chisera ; will you repair this damage , or will you die for it ?

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: As her eye travels the circle of the camp .I do not find the taste of life so sweet that I should turn it twice upon my tongue ; but —Her gaze halts on SIMWA , and all the attention of the camp seems to hang a moment in suspense as SIMWA ignores her .Do I die , then ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Let Simwa die !

sp.speaker: INDIANS
sp.p: Ah — ah —!

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: What , old fox , are you out of cover at last ?

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: By whom trouble came into the camp , let it depart . Who prevented the wisdom of the gods at the throwing of the sacred sticks ? By whose counsel were our allies of Castac destroyed ? Who hardened the Chisera 's heart so that she kept not our foes from us ?

sp.speaker: INDIANS
sp.p: Simwa ! Simwa !

sp.speaker: PADAHOON
sp.p: Sons of the Bear , do you think to win favor of the gods when you have one who mocks them in your midst ? Would you see the backs of the Tecuyas ? Would you win to your homes again ? Let Simwa die !

sp.speaker: INDIANS
sp.p: Aye , aye . Let Simwa die ! A judgment ! A judgment !

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Aside to his wife .My quiver , hand me my quiver !

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Simwa , as thou art a son to me , I fear the charge is just . But do you entreat the Chisera to go before the gods for us , then will this evil pass .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Rising .And if I choose to have it said that when the tribesmen of Sagharawite took a woman to Council , only Simwa stood out against it ?

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Then must I give judgment .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Simwa !

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Folding his arms .It shall not be said of me that I have borne to take my life of a woman .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Whether you can bear it or not , it shall be said of you , for though I am unhappy , I am still the Chisera , and I declare unto you that neither the life nor the death of a broken man can avail to turn the gods . But you , Chief Rain Wind , and you tribesmen of Sagharawite ,— if you must visit the loss of my power , let it be on your own heads , for you only are blameworthy .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: This is no time for riddles , Chisera .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: I mean none . What did Simwa other to me than the occasion allowed him ? Was it his fault that he found me alone and love-hungry ? Was it he who ordered that I should live apart where no woman could see how my heart went and give me counsel ? Was it any fault but yours — you that kept me far from your huts lest I should see and carry word to the gods how unworthy you were ! You that feared yourselves lessened when I walked among you with my power — Ai ! Ai ! Did you think at all what became of the woman so long as you had my medicine to help you ?

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: Creeping forward .So I said , so I said from the beginning . She was taught to be a Chisera , but she was born a woman !Excitement among the women .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Your words are sharp , Chisera .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: The fact is sharper . It has eaten through my bosom .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: We meant the best — we judged you companioned by the gods .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Did ever a woman serve them the less because she had dealt with a man ? Nay , all the power of woman comes from loving and being loved , and now the bitterest of all my loss is to know that I have never had it .

div.stage: She draws up her blanket .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: And not you only —

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: You —?

div.stage: She turns away confounded .

sp.speaker: SIMWA
sp.p: Wife — wife — if she finds the gods again , they will surely kill me .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Let them . Though I am your wife , I am the Chief 's daughter , and the tribe is still something to me . I will save them if I can . Chisera —

div.stage: The CHISERA listens and turns slowly .

sp.speaker: CHIEF
sp.p: Is that my daughter ?

sp.speaker: TAVWOTS
sp.p: Hush ! Perhaps she will move her !

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Do you think yourself aggrieved so much , Chisera ? Come , I will match sorrow with you , I and all thesethe women surge forward, and the stakes shall be the people . Here is my pride that I throw down , in my bride year to know my husband an impostor . Have you any sorrow to match with that ?

sp.speaker: WACOBA
sp.p: Since you wish a man so much , Chisera , here is mine whom the vultures seek .

div.stage: The women part to show the dead man stark in his blanket .

sp.speaker: HAIWAI
sp.p: Would you have a child at your breast , Chisera , here is mine , for my milk is dried with hunger .

div.stage: She holds up her swaddled child which BRIGHT WATER takes and holds toward the CHISERA , who stands confused , for the first time acutely aware of their misery .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Measuring the effect of her words .Chisera , my breast is as fruitless as yours — but you ... you have ... good medicine .

sp.speaker: TIAWA
sp.p: Lay hold on the gods , Chisera , these are ills from which man cannot save us !

div.stage: The CHISERA throws out her hands to signify the loss of her power , her blanket slips to the ground and she covers her face with her hands .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Gone — gone ! It is gone from me !

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER
sp.p: Signing to the women to hide the blanket .By dancing you shall bring it back again — for the sake of the women and children — dance , Chisera !

div.stage: Her voice has a kindling sound , and the women echo it with a breath .

sp.speaker: THE CHISERA
sp.p: Oh , I have danced until the earth under me is beaten to dust , and my heart is as dry as the dust , and all my songs have fallen to the ground .She begins to walk up and down excitedly .With what cry shall I call on the gods , now my songs are departed ?She begins to chant .And my heart is emptied of all But the grief of women .The women watch her breathlessly ; as she gradually swings into the dance , they seem to urge her with the stress of their anxiety .All the anguish of women , It smells to the gods As the dead after battle , It sounds in my heart As the hollow drums calling to battle , And the gods come quickly .

div.stage: As she falters the tribe surges forward .

sp.speaker: TRIBE
sp.p: Dance , Chisera , dance !She tries again and no strength comes — the men hold up their hands , palms outward , in the sign of prayer . The drum begins hollowly .Come , O my power , Indwelling spirit ! It is I that call . Childless , unmated —Drums and rattles are brought out , at first cautiously , lest she take alarm and be turned from her purpose , but as the fervor of her dancing increases , with increased confidence . SIMWA remains seated at one side , watching her , his foot touching his quiver . PADAHOON , who has moved over near him , observes him narrowly in the interval of dancing . CHISERA sings .Nay , I shall mate with the gods , And the tribesmen shall be my children . Rise up in me , O , my power , On the wings of eagles ! Return on me as the rain The earth renewing , Make my heart fruitful To nourish my children .

div.stage: SIMWA is seen to strip the magic arrow from his quiver .

sp.speaker: BRIGHT WATER

div.p: GLOSSARY OF INDIAN WORDS AND PHRASES

The names and phrases used in The Arrow-Maker were chosen from the culture area comprising the central valleys of California , from tribes belonging to or affiliated with the Paiute group . Exact definitions could not always be ascertained and frequently the meaning given by different villages differed widely . Whenever possible the nomenclature of the locality in which the incident occurred is preferred .
Choco . “ Fatty ”; a nickname of doubtful origin , possibly from the Spanish Chopo .
Pamaquash . “ Very tall ”; the Paiute equivalent of Longfellow .
Castac . “ Place of Springs ”; a small valley in the southerly Sierra , from which the inhabitants take their name .
Yavi . A common given name , meaning unknown .
Tavwots . “ Mighty Hunter ”; a name given to the rabbit in Paiute lore .
Seegooche . “ Woman who gives good things to eat .” Lady Bountiful .
Tiawa . A familiar title frequently given to old women , like “ Grannie .”
Wacoba . “ Flower of the Oak ”; oak tassel , also the plume of the quail .
Chisera . Medicine Woman ; witch . ( See last chapter of The Flock for account of the original Medicine Woman from whom the character was drawn . )
Tuiyo . “ Shining ”; very bright .
Pioke . “ Dew drop .”
Simwa . Applied in humorous sense , meaning a “ swell .”
Padahoon . The Sparrow Hawk .
Tecuya . Oak thicket , encinal .
Pahrump . Corn water . A place where there is water enough to grow a crop of corn .
Sagharawite . “ Place of the mush that was afraid .” An Indian village named from the quaking , gelatinous mush of acorn meal .
Paiute . More properly “ Pah Ute ”: the Utes who live by running water as distinguished from the Utes of the Great Basin ; one of the interior tribes of the Pacific Coast .
“ Friend of the Soul of Man .” The Great Spirit ; the Holy Ghost .
Toorape . “ Captain ”; chief ; a name given to one of the peaks of the Sierras .
“ The Sacred Sticks .” A number of small sticks with peculiar markings . Divination was practiced by throwing them on the ground and interpreting the pattern in which they fell .
Haiwai . “ The dove .”
Winnedumah . “ Standing Rock ”; a legendary hero .
Tinnemaha . Probably “ Medicine Water .” Mineral spring . Brother of the hero in the legend of Winnedumah .
“ Eaten meadowlarks ’ tongues .” Said of one nimble of wit . With the idea that like cures like , Indians were accustomed to feed backward or defective children with associated parts of animals .
Whenonabe . Bitter brush ; a decoction of the bark producing colic and griping ; a symbol of disaster .
“ Rattle-weed .” Astragalus ; produces madness when eaten .
“ Toyon .” California Christmas Berry .
“ Snake-in-the-grass ... tattle to the gods .” Snakes are believed to be the messengers and familiars of the gods ; therefore the Paiutes tell no important matter in the summer when they are about .
“ To dig roots before her wedding year is out .” A curse equivalent to barrenness . The work of digging roots was not performed by expectant mothers .

“ Wickiup .” A wattled hut of brush , made by planting willow poles about a pit four or five feet deep and six to eight feet in diameter . The poles were then drawn over in a dome and thatched with reeds or brush .
“ Campody .” An Indian village ; from the Spanish campo .
Barranca . A bank , the abrupt face of a mesa . From the Spanish .
THE DANCES
All tribal or emotional occasions among Indians are invariably accompanied by singing and dancing . These are frequently derived from the movements of animals and are both pantomimic and symbolic .
The object of the medicine dance is to work up the dancer to a state of trance , in which he receives a revelation in regard to the matter under consideration .

Some of these medicine dances are ritualistic in character and must be performed with great strictness , but in the case of the Chisera the dance is assumed to be made up of various dance elements expressing the emotion of the moment , combined by individual taste and skill .

Power is supposed to descend upon the dancer as he proceeds . Sometimes the dance lasts for hours , and even for days before the proper trance condition is attained . Even then the revelation may not come until a second or third climax has been reached .

The blanket dance is common throughout the Southwest , and possibly elsewhere . It is accompanied by a song which says , in effect , “ How lovely it will be when you and I have but one blanket .” By the young people it is not taken any more seriously than “ drop the handkerchief ” and other courtship games .
COSTUMES
While the scene of this play is laid among the Paiute peoples , there is nothing which makes it absolutely unlikely among any of the hunting tribes .

Considerable latitude is therefore permissible in costume and accessories . The only indispensable thing is that all these should be kept within a given culture area . Every article of Indian use or apparel is determined by some condition of living , and it is a mistake to mix costumes from various tribes .

Concessions must be made to the objections of the modern audience to the state of nudity which would be natural to the time in which the story is laid . But even making allowance for this , the tendency is always to overdo , to have too many beads and fringes and war-bonnets . No more than his white brother did the Indian wear all his best clothes every day .
The blanket is the most considerable item of Indian equipment . At once by its quality , its color , and its pattern it announces something of the wearer 's rank and condition .

The way in which it is worn betrays the state of his mind as does no other garment . It is drawn up , shrugged off , swung from one shoulder , or completely shrouds the figure according as his mood runs , or it is folded neatly about the body to get it out of the way of his arms when he has need of them . Blankets would be worn to Council , but not going to battle . They would be worn by young and modest women on public occasions , but by old women only for warmth and protection . They are also worn as an advertisement of the desire for privacy .

When an Indian is seen completely shrouded in his blanket , standing or sitting a little apart from the camp , he either has a grouch or he is praying . In either case it is not good manners to interrupt him .
As far as possible the use of the blanket is indicated in the text . Always it may be safely taken as an indication of the wearer 's attitude toward whatever is going on about him .
